document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the spider genus Sparianthis Simon, 1880 (Araneae, Sparassidae Sparianthinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the spider genus Sparianthis Simon, 1880 (Araneae, Sparassidae Sparianthinae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 93–96.
Sparianthis juruti
sp. nov.
, habitus. 93–94 male (MPEG 30645) (93 dorsal, 94 ventral); 95–96 female, paratype (MPEG 30819) (95 dorsal, 96 ventral). Scale lines: 2 mm.

FIGURES 97–101.
Sparianthis juruti
sp. nov.
97–99 male (IBSP 30645), left palp (97 prolateral, 98 ventral, 99 retrolateral); 100–101 female, paratype (MPEG 8563) (100 epigyne, 101 vulva). Scale lines: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology . The specific name refers to the collection locality of the holotype ; noun in apposition.

Diagnosis . Males of
S. juruti
sp. nov.
resemble those of
S. picta
by the palpal tibia with strong medial-retrolateral spine ( Figs 104 , 124 ). They are distinguished from the latter species by the spine two times longer than wide (at least three times longer than wide in
S. picta
) ( Fig. 104 ). They are further distinguished from all other species of the genus by TBE reduced and embolus with sub-distal pointed projection ( Fig. 105 ). Females resemble those of
S. humaita
sp. nov.
by the epigyne with anterior atrium grooved ( Figs 83 , 106 ). They are distinguished from the latter species by atrium rounded anteriorly (trapezoid in
S. humaita
sp. nov.
) ( Fig. 106 ), internal ducts slender, half spermathecae width, and first turn posteriad (internal ducts as wide as spermathecae width and first turn mediad
S. humaita
sp. nov.
) ( Figs 107–108 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 102–108.
Sparianthis juruti
sp. nov.
102–104 male, paratype (MPEG 30648), left palp (102 prolateral, 103 ventral, 104 retrolateral); 105 male (MPEG 30642) detail of embolus, retrolateral; 106–108 female, paratype (MPEG 30736) (106 epigyne, 107 vulva, 108 schematic course of internal duct structure). Scale lines: 1 mm. af = anterior furrow; ap = apical projection; dRTA = dorsal branch of RTA; lf = lateral furrow; mRTA = medial branch of RTA; sp = subdistal projection of embolus; TBC = tegular projection at base of conductor; TBE = tegular projection at embolus base; vRTA = ventral branch of RTA.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Female ( paratype , MPEG 30653):
Coloration pattern as in male, except opisthosoma densely covered by irregular elongate marks, 5–6 barely distinguishable median chevrons on posterior half and one pair of rounded pale brown muscle impressions on each side of cardiac mark; ventrally with elongate marks laterally and three median, wide, longitudinal stripes converging into irregular cup-shaped mark; muscle sigilla inconspicuous ( Figs 95–96 ). Total length 7.6. Prosoma: 3.3 long, 3.0 wide. Opisthosoma: 4.2 long, 2.5 wide. Eyes: diameters: 0.25, 0.22, 0.13, 0.20; interdistances: 0.20, 0.12, 0.36, 0.27, 0.16, 0.07. Legs (4213): I: 9.3 (2.8, 1.6, 2.3, 2.1, 0.5); II: 9.5 (3.1, 1.6, 2.2, 2.1, 0.5); III: 8.4 (2.6, 1.4, 1.9, 2.0, 0.5); IV: 10.0 (2.8, 1.3, 2.3, 2.8, 0.8). Spination follows the generic pattern, except metatarsi I–III: v2-0-0. Metatarsus III–IV with ventral distal preening combs. Epigyne: epigynal field sub-rectangular, longer than wide, rounded anteriorly; median septum 1.5 times longer than wide, widest medially with posterior margin rounded ( Figs 100 , 106 ). Vulva: glandular projection rounded, arising from duct between copulatory opening and first turn; spermathecae elongate, irregular-shaped ( Figs 101 , 107–108 ).
Variation . Males (n = 10): total length 5.5–6.6; prosoma length: 2.9–3.3; femur I length 2.6–3.2. Females (n = 10): total length 6.1–9.2; prosoma length 3.1–3.6; femur I length 2.4–3.0.
Distribution . Known from Brazil , western state of Pará , in the lower Amazon region ( Fig. 143 ).
